_header: Father and Son and Holy Ghost / That art one God of mights most
Note: For extracts occurring separately see 846 and 1545.
_description: Robert of Brunne, Handlyng Synne — 12630 lines in couplets

Bod415.First Lines:
FAdyr and sone & holygostþat art o god of myȝtys
                    most…
Bod415.Last Lines:
…But graunte vs alle vs self to ȝemeAnd yn our shryfte
                    Ihesu to queme
Bod415.Attributed Title:
Here begynneþ þe boke þat men clepen yn frenshe manuele
                    pecche þe wheche boke made yn frenshe Roberd Grosteste Bysshop of lyncolne
                    (f. 1)
Bod415.Editions:
Vanderschaaf,  B. M.,
                        ed.  
             “An Edition of Robert Mannyng’s Handlyng Synne.” 
         Diss. University of Iowa, 1978 [Bodley 415]. 
Sullens,  Idelle,
                        ed.  
             Robert Mannyng of Brunne: Handlyng Synne.
         Binghamton, NY: Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies, 1983.

CULIi49.First Lines:
The fyrste commawndmet of ych eonThou xalt haue non god but
                    on…
CULIi49.Last Lines:
…to com to heuen at domus daynow god god vs graunt þat it
                    so beAmen for charyte
CULIi49.Note:
Lacks Prologue. For the ‘Continuation’, see 378, 1598, 3099, 3339, 3355, 3358, and Sullivan (1978)
XSullivan,  S. A. 
             “Handlyng Synne in Its Tradition: A Study of Robert Mannyng of
                Brunne’s Handlyng Synne and Its Relation to Other Instructional Works, in
                Order to Establish the Place of the Poem in Its Genre.” 
         Diss. Cambridge, 1978.

BLHar1701.First Lines:
Fadyr and sone & holy gosteÞat art o god of myȝtes
                    moste…
BLHar1701.Last Lines:
…But graunte vs alle vs self to ȝemeAnd yn oure shryfte
                    Ihesu to queme
BLHar1701.Note:
The text finishes on the top half of the page, spanning both
                    columns.
BLHar1701.Attributed Author: Roberd Gros test Bysshop of Lyncolne (f. 1)
BLHar1701.Attributed Title:
Here bygynneþ the boke þat men clepyn yn frenshe manuele pecche
                    þe whych boke made yn frenshe Roberd Gros test Bysshop of Lyncolne
                    (rubricated RT, f. 1)
BLHar1701.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Robert of Brunne’s Handlyng Synne, written in 1203, with the
                French Treatise on which it is founded, Le Manuel des Pechiez by William of
                Waddington.
Roxburghe Club.
         London: J. B. Nichols and Son, 1862. 
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Robert of Brunne’s Handlyng Synne [and its French
                original]
EETS
         o.s. 119, 123 (1901, 1903); repr. 1973. 
Sisam,  Celia,  and  Kenneth Sisam, eds.  
             The Oxford Book of Medieval English Verse.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1970: 145-54.

Dulwich24.First Lines:
FAder & sone & holy gostþat is oo god & myȝt
                    haþ mostAt his wurschepe we schul be gynneto schame þe fend
                    and schone synne…
Dulwich24.Last Lines:
…for he a vowede & trust not& ȝit in dede wel
                    wers he wroutseunt Austyn seith a redy wayto ȝow þat dar I
                    wel say…
Dulwich24.Note:
Ends imperfectly at line 2894 (see Sullens (1983)
XSullens,  Idelle. 
             Robert Mannyng of Brunne: Handlyng Synne.
         Binghamton, NY: Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies, 1983, p. 74).
                    Catchphrase at foot of f. 21v: ‘ȝoure wikkid vowys’.
                    Written two lines of verse per manuscript line except for the first eight lines.
                    Lines 1-4 repeated at top (two lines per one), but text is smudged as if someone
                    attempted to rub them out. The scribe writes ᰰAmen quod a
                                 Rose’ in the lower margin of
                    f. 16.

YaleBeiOsa2.First Lines:
…The angell saw he gan a bydeComforþthe he sayde and ye
                    noȝt hydeOf þis fyre na drede ye noȝteBot with wrange
                    yf þu toke oghte…
YaleBeiOsa2.Last Lines:
…It may noghte be for no nedþat gode wylde he sulde for
                    bedeSen he for bede it it sulde be noghte
YaleBeiOsa2.Note:
Listed as ‘Osborn 5’ in Robbins  and  Cutler (1965)
XRossell Hope Robbins,   and  John L. Cutler.  
             Supplement to the Index of Middle English Verse.
         Lexington, Kentucky: University of Kentucky Press, 1965; begins
                    and ends imperfectly, with modern note ‘2500’ beside first line and
                    modern ‘12363’ beside last line.
YaleBeiOsa2.Editions:
Schulz,  S. A.,
                        ed.  
             “An Edition of Robert Mannyng of Brunne’s Handlyng Synne (Osborn
                MS).” 
         Diss. New York University, 1973.
